lines.value: the battle of yorktown also called the siege of yorktown fought from september 28-october 19 1781
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is considered the last major land battle of the american revolutionary war
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the continental army led by general george washington won a decisive victory against the british army led by general lord charles cornwallis
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: cornwallis was forced to surrender after being surrounded by washington's army
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the americans were assisted by the french led by the comte de rochambeau
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the battle took place in yorktown virginia near the york river
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: after the french fleet defeated a british fleet cornwallis was cut off and had to surrender to the french and the continental army
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: eventually it led to the treaty of paris in 1783 two years later
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: british general lord cornwallis had fought against the americans in 1776 and 1777
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he was convinced the americans could not defeat a british army in the field
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in 1778 he returned to england to care for his wife who died in february of 1779
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: after a few months he returned to america to continue the fight
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: while he was gone there was a change in british strategy
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: before the british had concentrated on defeating and destroying washington's army
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: now since the french had joined the americans it was no longer just a rebellion but an international conflict
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: earlier the french had been helping the americans with loans and war supplies
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: now they were actively fighting against the british who had to move some troops from north america to defend its interests elsewhere
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the new strategy was to win back the southern colonies beginning with georgia
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the british thought that as many as 50 percent of the population in the south was loyal to britain
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they would start with georgia and move north through the carolinas to the virginia colony
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: on his arrival in new york city cornwallis was made second in command to general henry clinton
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the two generals did not trust each other
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: clinton was convinced washington would attack him in new york
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he was afraid of sending troops home and having to depend more on loyalist militia
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: cornwallis was ready to go ahead with what troops he had
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: clinton was suspicious cornwallis return from england was to get a command for himself
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in fact cornwallis had secured a commission to replace clinton if clinton repeated his threats to resign
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: clinton sent cornwallis south to recapture charleston south carolina following the new plan
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: soon cornwallis began acting independently of clinton who stayed safe in new york city
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: cornwallis wasn't going to play it safe and advance by careful steps as he had been instructed
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when he saw a chance to attack the new patriot army under major general horatio gates he did so without orders nearly wiping out the americans
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: cornwallis moved carelessly
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he left american units such as the one lead by francis marion called the swamp fox in his rear
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the american general nathanael greene noticed this right away
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he broke up his command into smaller units in order to plague cornwallis
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: finally the two armies met at the battle of guilford court house which neither army won
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: during this time cornwallis was not sending messages to clinton telling him where he was
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: after guilford court house cornwallis moved to the coast of north carolina to rest his men
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: then again without orders he decided to march north to virginia
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: frustrated by this clinton sent cornwallis a number of contradictory messages
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: most of them were worded as suggestions rather than orders
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: but he did order cornwallis to find a defensible position
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this was so he could be evacuated by the royal navy possibly to philadelphia
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: cornwallis decided on the community of yorktown and his men started building defenses there in august of 1781 to wait for the navy
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in new york washington learned that the french admiral francois joseph paul de grasse was sailing north from the west indies
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: rochambeau convinced washington they could attack and defeat cornwallis
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the two commanders began marching south to meet de grasse's 27 ships and 3200 troops
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: clinton learned of this and sent a british naval fleet to the chesapeake bay to cut them off
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: but the french and americans arrived first
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the battle of the chesapeake the french navy forced the british ships back to new york city
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: clinton warned cornwallis in early september he would soon be facing american and french troops but promised him reinforcements by sea
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: clinton had not yet learned of the french naval victory and did not know he could not rescue cornwallis by sea
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: by the end of september washington and rochambeau had surrounded yorktown
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: cornwallis received another message in late september from clinton telling him help was on the way
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: cornwallis was misled again and thought he only had to hold out for a few days
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: just after the clash between the french and british fleets a smaller french squadron carrying the french army's siege artillery slipped into the chesapeake
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: now the french and americans had bigger guns than cornwallis had behind his fortifications
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: marching out of williamsburg virginia the americans and french arrived on september 28 1781 at yorktown
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they surrounded the s in a semicircle with the york river completing the circle
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: cornwallis made the first move abandoning his outer works made up of four redoubts
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: washington and rochambeau thought this was a mistake
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they sent troops to occupy the outer earthworks
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the americans and french began setting up their siege operations on september 30 first on the east side
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: by october 9 they were close enough to begin the bombardment
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the americans and french stormed two of the redoubts on october 14 forcing the british back even further
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: by that time it became obvious the british could not hold out much longer
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: on october 16 the british attacked two of the redoubts they had abandoned and spiked the guns
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: at the same time cornwallis attempted to slip past the s to gloucester now gloucester point virginia across the river but was turned back by a storm
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: finally with no sign of relief as promised by clinton cornwallis army of 6000 soldiers surrendered
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the casualties were about 500 british 200 french and 80 americans
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: captured were 240 artillery pieces a large supply of small arms and ammunition plus
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: general cornwallis did not attend the surrender
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: claiming to be sick he sent general charles o'hara to surrender for him
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: o'hara first tried to surrender to comte de rochambeau
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: rochambeau directed him to surrender to general washington
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in turn washington directed him to surrender to general benjamin lincoln who accepted o'hara's sword
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: as the british stacked their guns marching out of the fortress their band played the world turned upside down
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when lord north the british prime minister received news of the surrender he cried out oh god it is all over
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the battles of saratoga in 1777 and yorktown in 1781 were two major turning points in the revolutionary war
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: both were american victories over the british but with very different results
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the british defeat at saratoga prolonged the war while the battle at yorktown foretold its end
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: saratoga convinced the french to join the americans against the british
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: yorktown was a joint victory by the french and the americans over the british
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: france and her allies continued to fight hard for two more years but there was little fighting anymore on the american continent
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the treaty of paris 1783 ended the war

lines.value: dynamite is an explosive invented by alfred nobel
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: its main explosive component is nitroglycerin
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: nitroglycerin is very sensitive to movement
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it explodes very easily when moved
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: for this reason diatomaceous earth is used to take away this sensitivity
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in dynamite about one part of four is diatomaceous earth the other three are nitroglycerin
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a little sodium carbonate is added to stabilise the mixture
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: even though the diatomaceous earth takes away some of the dangers of nitroglycerin there are still problems because the mixture is not stable in damp environments
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: dynamite that is damp or even wet slowly loses its nitroglycerin
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the nitroglycerin can build up and explode unexpectedly
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: for this reason the formulation was changed
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: instead of diatomaceous earth gelignite was used to hold the nitroglycerin
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: gelignite holds the nitroglycerin so that it cannot dissolve in water
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: today dynamite is no longer used commercially
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it has been replaced by explosives based on ammonium nitrate which use gelignite
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: these explosives are cheaper to produce and easier to handle than dynamite
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: however dynamite still used in movies and television

lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the materials are inspired by the factories and warehouses of chicago's south side and embod[y] 20th century methods and materials steel and concrete frames with curtain walls of brick and glass alfred caldwell designed the campus landscape
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: caldwall was van der rohe's close colleague at iit and was called the last representative of the prairie school of landscape architects known as the nature poet caldwell's plan reinforced van der rohe's design with landscaping planted in a free flowing manner which in its interaction with the pristine qualities of the architecture introduce[d] a poetic aspect on the west side of main campus are three red brick buildings that were original to armour institute built between 1891 and 1901
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in 1938 ludwig mies van der rohe began his 20-year tenure as director of iit's school of architecture 1938-1959
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the university was on the verge of building a brand new campus to be one of the nation's first federally funded urban renewal projects
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: mies was given great freedom in the large project
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the university grew fast enough during and after world war ii to allow much of the new plan to be realized
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: from 1943 to 1957 several new mies buildings rose across campus including the sr crown hall which houses the architecture school and was designated a national historic landmark in 2001
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: though mies had emphasized his wish to complete the campus he had begun commissions from the late 50s onward were given to skidmore owings and merrill som prompting mies to never return to the campus that had changed architecture the world over
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: som architect walter netsch designed a few buildings including the new library that mies had wished to create all of them similar to mies's style
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: by the late 1960s campus addition projects were given to som's myron goldsmith who had worked with mies during his education at iit and thus was able to design several new buildings to harmonize well with the original campus
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in 1976 the american institute of architects recognized the campus as one of the 200 most significant works of architecture in the united states

lines.value: the new campus center designed by rem koolhaas and a new state of the art residence hall designed by helmut jahn state street village opened in 2003

lines.value: down syndrome or trisomy 21 old name mongoloid idiocy is a genetic disorder
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: people with down syndrome have an extra copy of chromosome 21 or part of it.down syndrome causes a mental handicap
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it may be mild or severe
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the average iq of a young adult with down syndrome is 50 equivalent to the mental age of an 8 or 9-year-old child but it truly depends on the person
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this can vary widely but most individuals need supervision if they are to live their lives in a satisfactory way
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: children who have this condition take more time to learn new things
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the condition is named after john langdon down the british doctor who first described it in 1866
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he called it mongoloid idiocy because he thought that children with down syndrome had faces like that of blumenbach's mongolian race
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: idiocy meant intellectual disability
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: people do not use the term mongoloid idiocy today
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is a disparaging or disrespectful term
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there is sometimes discrimination against people with down syndrome both in the education system and in society in general
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: some people with the condition have average intelligence but may have other problems with development instead
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: people with down syndrome often have a different shape of eyes than most people
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a few people with the condition have severe learning difficulties
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: of every 800 to 1000 babies that are born one is diagnosed with down syndrome
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: older women have a higher chance of having a baby with down syndrome
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: if they have a procedure known as amniocentesis pregnant mothers can be told whether their foetus has down syndrome
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sound scans may also diagnose the presence of down syndrome
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: mothers whose foetus is diagnosed as having downs syndrome may choose to have an abortion
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the united kingdom and europe 92% of such cases are aborted
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they also grow differently from other children
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: babies with down syndrome can be identified at birth because they may have a specific set of physical features
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: these features include narrow eyes a flat nose bridge smaller mouths and shorter fingers
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: smaller mouths can result in tongue protrusion or what looks like a large tongue
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sometimes the little fingers curve inwards as well and there is also often a space between the big toe and the others
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: people with down syndrome often have heart defects or alzheimer's disease when they are older
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: about 90% of people with down syndrome live through their teens
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the lifespan of a person with down syndrome averages between 50 and 55 years old
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: so far there have been no treatments for down syndrome
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: down syndrome comes from a problem with the genes
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: humans are diploid organisms
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this means that for each chromosome there are two copies one from the mother and one from the father
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: during meiosis the number is reduced to one set of chromosomes
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: people with down syndrome have an extra copy of chromosome 21 or part of it.there are three ways that down syndrome is caused
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the most common cause of down syndrome is trisomy
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: trisomy is when the child receives two chromosomes from the mother and one from the father
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this makes it so there are three chromosomes of chromosome 21
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: another way down syndrome is caused is when new cells are made
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sometimes even when the parent cells are normal chromosome 21 can be deformed when cells reproduce
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this makes it so some cells have 47 chromosomes and others have 46
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this is called a mosaic disorder
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: mosaic means that they have a third chromosome from the replication of cells
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the third way down syndrome can be caused is called translocation
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this happens when a normal chromosome breaks into two pieces
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this results in three chromosomes
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: for comprehensive lists of down syndrome links see
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: biogeography is the study of how species are distributed
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it aims to show where organisms live and why they are or are not found in a certain geographical area
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the basic issue is that animals and plants are adapted to the places they live in but similar places often have quite different animals and plants
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: one might expect to find for example that the animals in a tropical rain forest would be almost the same in amazonia equatorial africa and southeast asia
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: but that is not the case
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there must be reasons for this situation
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: those reasons are the subject of research in biogeography
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: at first from about 1800 1855 natural historians made lists of species in various regions of the world
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: these lists were published as tables in their books
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a revolution started with charles darwin and alfred russel wallace who published the idea of evolution by natural selection
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they had travelled in tropical countries and wrote about the life in those countries
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they said that evolution was the key to understanding geographical distribution
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: new species usually come about by an earlier species splitting in two speciation
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this takes place at a certain time and place
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: from that place the new species may travel
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it will be blocked by geographical features seas mountains and by climate
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: thus a species may never get to other places where it might be a great success
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: that in general is the reason why lands with similar climate often have quite different animals and plants
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: classic examples are australian marsupials and the great american interchange
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: of course different types of animals and plants have different
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is easier for birds and insects to travel by flight and in the sea fish can easily travel
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: all the same there are limits
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: fish on either side of the americas are usually different species and fresh water fish do not disperse much
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: so it comes about that :"the more distant countries are the more dissimilar are their animals and plants and the nearer they are the more similar are their animals and plants
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the scientific theory of biogeography grows out of the work of alexander von humboldt 1769-1859 hewett cottrell watson 1804-1881 alphonse de candolle 1806-1893 alfred russel wallace 1823-1913 philip lutley sclater 1829-1913 and other biologists and explorers
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: wallace studied the distribution of flora and fauna in the amazon basin and the malay archipelago in the mid 19th century
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: wallace and sclater saw biogeography as a source of support for the theory of evolution
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: key findings such as the sharp difference in fauna either side of the wallace line can only be understood in this light
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: otherwise the field of biogeography would be a purely descriptive one
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: both darwin galapagos islands and wallace gave a great deal of attention to islands as offering examples of evolution especially speciation
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this interest was revived by the theory of island biogeography by robert macarthur and eo wilson in 1967
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they showed that the species richness of an area could be predicted if one knew the habitat area immigration rate and extinction rate
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: also it was realised that habitat fragments are rather like islands
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they can be investigated by the same methods
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this spurred the development of conservation biology
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: genome analysis allows scientists to test theories about the origin and dispersal of populations such as island species
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it allows biologists to test theories about where the species come from
lines.name: Simple English

lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: ethology is the scientific study of animal behaviour us behavior and a sub topic of zoology
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: ethology overlaps to some extent with psychology
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: psychology is a social science which studies human behaviour but many psychologists have done experiments on learning in animals
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: ethology studies animal behaviour but many ethologists have been interested in human behaviour
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: an american specialist on ants william morton wheeler first used the term ethology in english in 1902
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the study of animal behaviour which had been going on in an way since aristotle had its roots in natural history
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it became more scientific during the 19th century
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the french zoologist etienne geoffroy saint hilaire was the founder of ethology in europe and his son isidore produced a three volume encyclopaedia histoire naturelle generale
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the third volume he talked about animal behaviour in almost modern terms
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the entomologist j.-h fabre 1823-1915 was a remarkable observer of natural life
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: his popular writing on natural history kept ethology alive in europe
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: douglas spalding 1841-1877 was a british biologist who was the first to notice the effect called imprinting
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: instinct and imprinting were the first scientific concepts in ethology
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he was able to prove that the behaviour of chicks after hatching from the egg happened even when they had no experience practice or even information from the senses
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: therefore the capacity was inherited
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: studies by charles otis whitman oskar heinroth and julian huxley set the tone in the 20th century
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this work was mostly on bird behaviour especially mating behaviour
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the behaviour of birds played a big part in early ethology but there was a start to studying our nearest relatives
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: wolfgang kohler's mentality of apes was a landmark in the study of primates
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the next generation began during the 1930s with the work of austrian biologists konrad lorenz and karl von frisch and the dutch biologist niko tinbergen
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the three men were joint winners of the nobel prize in physiology or medicine for 1973
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: lorenz is famous for his longitudinal studies he lived with the animals he researched and made observations throughout their lives
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: then he wrote about what he had discovered in long very readable papers
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he researched instinctual behaviour which he called fixed action patterns faps
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: lorenz popularized faps as instinctive responses that would occur reliably in the presence of specific stimuli called sign stimuli or releasing stimuli
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: von frisch worked on communication in honey bees the famous bee dances
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: tinbergen experimented with the stimuli which trigger fixed action patterns
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he found out that artificial super stimuli could often work better than the natural stimuli
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: ethology is a combination of laboratory and field science with a strong relation to certain other disciplines - e.g neuroanatomy ecology evolution
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: ethologists are typically interested in a behavioural process rather than in a particular animal group and often study one type of behaviour e.g ) in a number of unrelated animals
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the 1960s nico tinbergen set out a framework for research on behaviour
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it involved four questions and their answers
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: * function - how does the behaviour affect the animal's chances of survival and reproduction
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: why does the animal respond that way instead of some other way
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the only scientific explanation for an animal's behaviour is that it is well adapted for survival and reproduction in its environment
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a trait is the result of its past contribution to survival
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in practice this is simple
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: for instance birds fly south in the winter to find food and warmth and mammalian mothers nurture their young thereby having more surviving offspring
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: * causation - what are the stimuli that trigger the response and how has it been modified by recent learning
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: * evolutionary history - how does the behaviour compare with similar behaviour in related species and how might it have begun through the process of phylogeny
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: phylogeny explains why some adaptation is less than perfect
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: from where it is there are always some possibilities which a particular species can never get to
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this is because all stages in evolution must be viable else extinction occurs
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: another reason is that not all traits of a species can be maximised at the same time
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: increase in armour for example is bound to slow down movement
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: teeth which are best for vegetation are much less good for meat
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the final result is a set of traits most of which are sub optimal
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: earlier phylogenetic stages and pre- conditions which persist often determine the form of more modern characteristics
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: for instance the vertebrate eye including the human eye has a blind spot whereas octopus eyes do not
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: once the vertebrate eye had evolved the only way it could improve was to minimise the effect of the blind spot
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: we don't notice it ordinarily because with binocular vision what one eye misses the other fills in
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: * development - how does the behaviour change with age and what early experiences are necessary for the behaviour to be displayed
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: all instances of behaviour require an explanation at each of these four levels
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: for example the function of eating is to acquire nutrients which ultimately aids survival and reproduction but the immediate cause of eating is hunger causation
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: hunger and eating are evolutionarily ancient and are found in many species evolutionary history and develop early within an organism's lifespan development
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is easy to confuse such questions - for example to argue that people eat because they're hungry and not to acquire nutrients - without realizing that the reason people experience hunger causation is because it causes them to acquire nutrients function
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: james watt 19 january 1736 19 august 1819 was a scottish mathematician and engineer
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he did not invent the first steam engine but he did modify it to work better
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there were other patented steam engines such as the savery and newcomen steam engines in use by the time watt started his work on them
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: his major contribution is in developing the modern form of the steam engine
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the watt steam engine is credited for driving the industrial revolution of the 18th and 19th centuries
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: james watt was a brilliant engineer and he also transformed the newcomen engine
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: today most people honor him by naming a unit of power the watt after him
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: james watt was born on 19 january 1736 in greenock renfrewshire a seaport on the firth of clyde
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: his father was a shipwright ship owner and contractor and served as the town's chief baillie while his mother agnes muirhead came from a distinguished family and was well educated
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: both were presbyterians and strong covenanters
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: watt's grandfather thomas watt taught mathematics and was a baillie to the baron of cartsburn
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: watt did not go to school every day
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: at first he was mostly schooled at home by his mother but later he attended greenock grammar school
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he exhibited great manual dexterity and an aptitude for mathematics although latin and greek failed to interest him and he absorbed the legends and lore of the scottish people
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: one of watt's many improvements was the invention of a centrifugal governor to regulate automatically the speed of the engine
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this is most obvious on steam engines where it regulates the admission of steam into the cylinder(s
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is also found on internal combustion engines and variously fueled turbines and in some modern striking clocks
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a centrifugal governor is a homeostatic device which controls the speed of an engine by regulating the amount of intermediate substance steam which drives the machine
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this keeps a near constant speed whatever the load or fuel supply conditions
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it uses the principle of proportional control this means the cut off of in this case steam varies according to the speed of the machine
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: on watt's fly ball device as the machine speeds up the balls fly round faster
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: as they fly round faster they move out from the central post
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: as they move out from the central post they close the steam supply more firmly
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: as they do so the machine slows down and the balls spin more slowly and allow more steam into the cylinders
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in addition the system has a safety release valve to allow excess steam to escape without driving the wheels
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: 500 boulton & watt engines were built by the firm between 1775 and 1800
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: later this kind of feedback loop became an important tool of cybernetics
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: watt went into partnership with a fellow member of the midlands lunar society matthew boulton
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the firm of boulton & watt designed and built steam engines and was very important to the industrial revolution
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: at first the partnership made the drawing and specifications for the engines and supervised the work to erect it on the customer's property
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they produced almost none of the parts themselves
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: watt did most of his work at his home in harper's hill in birmingham while boulton worked at the soho manufactory
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: gradually the partners began to actually make more and more of the parts and by 1795 they purchased a property about a mile away from the soho manufactory on the banks of the birmingham canal
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there they built a new foundry for making the engines
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the soho foundry opened in 1796 at a time when watt's sons gregory and james jr were heavily involved in the management of the enterprise
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in 1800 the year of watt's retirement the firm made a total of forty one engines
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: watt retired in 1800 the same year that his fundamental patent and partnership with boulton expired
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the famous partnership was transferred to the men's sons matthew robinson boulton and james watt jr longtime firm engineer william murdoch was soon made a partner and the firm prospered
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: lady jane grey 1537-1554 also known as the nine days queen was born in london or at her family home of bradgate park leicestershire england
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: jane was an english noblewoman who occupied the english throne from 10 july until 19 july 1553 and was executed by decapitation a common punishment for royal blood for high treason
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a great granddaughter of henry vii by his younger sister mary jane was a first cousin once removed of edward vi
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in may 1553 jane married lord guildford dudley a younger son of edward's chief minister john dudley duke of northumberland
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when the 15-year-old king lay dying in june 1553 he nominated jane as successor to the crown in his will thus subverting the claims of his half sisters mary and elizabeth
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: during her short reign jane lived in the tower of london
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she became a prisoner there as the privy council decided to change sides and proclaim mary as queen on 19 july 1553
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: wyatt's rebellion in january and february 1554 against queen mary's plans of a spanish match was the direct cause of jane's and her husband's execution
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she was the daughter of henry grey duke of suffolk and lady frances brandon 16 july 1517 - 20 november 1559 the daughter of henry viii's sister mary
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she was born on 12 october 1537 and she was probably named after jane seymour c
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: jane had two younger sisters catherine b
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: 1540 and mary b
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: jane's parents were very strict even by the standards of the day
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: if she made mistakes in her studies or had any other normal troubles her mother would slap her or beat her
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she found she loved her nurse but otherwise lived a sad childhood
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she told a visiting scholar roger ascham for when i am in the presence of either father or mother whether i speak keep silence sit stand or go eat drink be merry or sad be sewing playing dancing or doing anything else i must do it as it were in such weight measure and number even so perfectly as god made the world or else i am so sharply taunted so cruelly threatened yes presently sometimes with pinches nips and bobs and other ways that i think myself in hell
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when jane was nine she was sent to the royal court to learn etiquette and manners with henry viii's sixth wife and eventual widow catherine parr
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: jane liked catherine a great deal and found love with her which she had not got from her parents
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it was clear that catherine was very fond of jane in return
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: jane also found friendship with her cousin and future king edward vi
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they often studied together
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: jane was well educated as a child and learned to read in latin greek french and italian as well as english
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: later in her life she also learned hebrew
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: jane's parents especially her mother wanted to gain more political influence
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: for that reason they wanted to marry her to someone important
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: jane had two sisters catherine born in 1540 and mary born in 1545
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: after her sisters were born her parents tried to marry jane to her cousin edward vi
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they went to catherine parr's new husband thomas seymour to try to prepare this royal marriage
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is likely that king edward loved jane
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: however he decided to arrange a marriage with a foreign princess instead
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in 1548 jane was sent to chelsea to be with catherine parr and thomas seymour
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: catherine parr became pregnant that same year and the family moved to sudeley castle in june taking jane with them
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: tragedy struck when catherine parr died while having the baby in august of that year and jane served as chief mourner in her funeral
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: jane was dealt another blow in 1549 when thomas seymour was arrested on charges of treason
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she was sent back to her angered parents
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they knew that their hopes of her marriage to the king were ruined they punished her cruelly for this even though it was not her fault
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in 1551 jane's mother's two half brothers died of the sweating sickness
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: since frances's father was dead she became duchess of suffolk
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: jane's father also became duke of suffolk
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the same year john dudley was made the duke of northumberland and the chief councillor to edward vi
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in april 1552 edward became sick with the measles and caught tuberculosis as well
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: by next year edward was so ill that he was weak and spitting up blood or something that was greenish yellow
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it was clear that he was going to die soon
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: dudley knew that if either of edward's half sisters mary or elizabeth became queen he would not be powerful anymore
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: dudley plotted with jane's equally ambitious parents and planned that jane became his ward and also that she marry his son guildford dudley
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: jane's mother decided to give up her claim to be queen for jane
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this did not mean that frances was any less greedy however
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this meant that jane would become frances and dudley's puppet and do what they wanted
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: now jane would be the next in line to the throne if the rights of the princesses mary and elizabeth were ignored
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when jane's mother and father told her that jane was going to get married jane refused
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she said that guildford was ugly stupid and rude
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she also hated john dudley
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when jane refused frances and henry swore at jane and slapped her
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this did not work so frances gave jane a brutal whipping
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: finally jane agreed
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the wedding between jane and guildford happened on 25 may 1553
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this became a triple marriage because jane's sister katherine was married at this time to lord herbert and guildford's sister katherine was also married to lord hastings
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: on 6 july 1553 king edward vi died
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: dudley's plan to make jane queen was starting to take place
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: edward's death was kept secret for a few days until jane could be proclaimed queen
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: jane was told by her parents and john dudley that she was queen
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she became sick with fright and fainted
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she did not want to take the crown
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the crown is not my right
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it pleaseth me not
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the lady mary is the rightful heir jane said
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: her parents swore at her and john dudley told her that she doth wrong to herself and her house
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: under pressure jane finally relented
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: lady jane said she never forgave herself for doing this
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: meanwhile news was spreading the jane had been proclaimed the new queen
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: although the people liked jane they loved mary and elizabeth more
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they also did not like john dudley
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in east anglia mary was gaining support and planning to march into london
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: dudley tried to enforce a counter attack but to no avail
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: on 19 july mary became queen
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: jane was queen for nine days
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: jane returned all the crown jewels and clothes
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she was then brought into the tower of london
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there she was kept in a cell for the next few months
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: however she was allowed to walk in the garden
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she wrote many letters and read many books while at the tower of london
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she wrote a letter to queen mary saying that she never wanted the crown
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: queen mary believed jane and refused to execute her cousin
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: many people pressured mary but she was stubborn
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she still ordered that a trial be held for traditional purposes
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: jane was found guilty but the queen pardoned her
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: however the next year 1554 a group of rebels under thomas wyatt including jane's father henry grey led a rebellion against queen mary because she was planning to marry prince phillip ii of spain
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it was quickly put down
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: although jane had nothing to do with it and mary did not want to kill her cousin her advisors told her that phillip would only come if jane was killed
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: so with a heavy heart sadly queen mary signed the death warrant
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: jane was going to be beheaded
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when jane was told that her head was going to be cut off she was very scared
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: nonetheless she was happy that her sad and woeful days of life were finally coming to an end
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: meanwhile mary still did not want to kill her cousin
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: so she sent a catholic priest dr feckenham to try to convert jane to catholicism
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: that way jane would not be a threat
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: jane was a firm protestant and refused to become a catholic
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: jane's execution was postponed from 9 february to 12 february to try and make her a catholic
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the night before the execution jane wrote many letters to her family and prepared her neck for the block
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the next morning her hair was tied back and she watched guildford go very unwillingly to the block
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: then it was her turn
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: on 12 february 1554 at the tower of london jane was sent to the scaffold
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she calmly climbed the scaffold and said a speech
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she said the psalm 51 in the most devout manner
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she then knelt by the block and tied a piece of cloth around her eyes
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when the executioner told her to put her head on the block she reached out but could not find the block since she was very scared
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she cried for help until someone grabbed her hands and helped her find the block
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: jane then put her neck above the block and slowly lowered it onto the block pressed her neck against the wood and fit her chin in the hold
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: then she brought her arms around her
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: before she was executed she cried out lord into thy hands i commend my spirit some say her last words were the name of her much loved husband lord gilbert
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the crowd watched as the executioner raised the axe high in the air
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: jane was shivering badly but her neck stayed perfectly still
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: then the executioner quickly swung the axe down perfectly at the middle of jane's neck which was severed in a single stroke
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: jane's severed head fell to the straw in front of the block while huge amounts of blood splattered across the scaffold
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the executioner then grabbed jane's head by her red hair and lifted it up to show the crowd
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he shouted so perish all the queen's enemies
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: behold the head of a traitor but some sources suggest the fact that it took 3 shots to remove lady jane's head
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: after the crowd left the blood was removed and jane's body was brought to the church st peter ad vincula
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: since the church had just become catholic and jane was a protestant they had to get permission from queen mary to bury her
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it was four hours until her maids were allowed to prepare her body for burial
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: jane's body was buried between former queens anne boleyn and catherine howard
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is unknown what happened to her severed head

lines.value: anne boleyn 1501 or 1507 - 19 may 1536 was the second wife of king henry viii of england and queen consort from 1533 until 1536

lines.value: she was the mother of elizabeth i of england
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: anne has been called the most and important queen consort england has ever had it was because of anne boleyn that henry viii divorced catherine of aragon and became from the roman catholic church
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: after she was falsely accused of adultery incest and high treason she was executed
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there were many different opinions of anne's beauty
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the venetian diarist marino sanuto described anne as not one of the handsomest women in the world she is of middling complexion long neck wide mouth bosom not much raised eyes which are black and beautiful
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: simon grynee wrote to martin bucer in september 1531 that anne was young good looking of a rather dark complexion
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: lancelot de carles called her beautiful with a good figure
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a venetian in paris in 1528 also said that she was beautiful
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the most well known description of anne was written by the catholic nicholas sanders in 1586
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he wrote it several years after anne died
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: even though this is the most famous it is also probably the least correct description
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: anne boleyn he said was rather tall with black hair and an oval face of a sallow complexion as if troubled with jaundice
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she had a projecting tooth under the upper lip and on her right hand six fingers [which historians now say is not true]
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there was a large wen under her chin and therefore to hide its ugliness she wore a high dress covering her throat she was handsome to look at with a pretty mouth sanders said that it was because of anne that henry went away from the catholic church
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sanders words about anne made what eric ives called the monster legend of anne boleyn
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: anne was also a good dancer
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: william forrest who wrote a modern poem about catherine of aragon praised anne's dancing
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he said she had passing " skill as a dancer
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: here he wrote was [a] fresh young damsel that could trip and go
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: little is known for certain about anne's early life beginning with the date and location of her birth
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she was born in either 1501 or 1507 as one source says she was 20 upon her return from france in 1521 and another that she was not yet 29 at the time of her death in 1536
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the location was either blickling hall in norfolk or hever castle in kent
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she was the daughter of sir thomas boleyn a courtier and later a diplomat and his wife lady elizabeth howard daughter of the duke of norfolk
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she had two siblings a sister mary and a brother george
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: anne's early education was the same for girls of her class
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: her academic education was limited to arithmetic her family genealogy grammar history reading and writing
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she had been given a strong upbringing in religion and the scriptures as the boleyns were a family of firm religious beliefs
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: anne developed domestic skills such as dancing embroidery good manners and morals household management music needlework and singing and excelled in playing several musical instruments including the block flute the harp the lute and the virginals
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she learned to play games such as cards chess and dice and outdoor pursuits such as archery falconry horseback riding and hunting
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: anne was also taught to have obedience to the men in her life was which first to her father and then to her husband once she was married
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in 1513 she was sent to margaret of austria's royal court in the netherlands to complete her education
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: anne learned to speak french and studied art culture dance literature music and poetry while she was there

lines.value: the following year she was transferred to the french court on the occasion of the marriage of princess mary tudor younger sister of king henry viii to the french king louis xii
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: anne remained in france after the death of louis xii and served as a lady in waiting to queen claude upon the accession of francis i in queen claude's household anne completed her study of french and developed a thorough knowledge of french culture and etiquette
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: as well as english french and some italian anne demonstrated a working knowledge of latin
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she also developed an interest in fashion and religious philosophy that called for reform of the church
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: anne stayed in france until late winter 1521
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: anne was called back to england to marry a distant cousin james butler in the hope to settle an inheritance dispute over the earldom of ormond
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: however when the plan failed thomas boleyn found a place for his daughter at the english court as lady in waiting to queen katherine
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there anne fell in love with sir henry percy who was the eldest son of the earl of northumberland and they became secretly engaged to be married much to the displeasure of their respective families
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: cardinal wolsey ordered them to be separated
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: anne was sent home to hever castle and henry percy was forced to marry lady mary talbot the daughter of edward talbot earl of shrewsbury
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: anne blamed cardinal wolsey for her lost love and was determined to have her revenge on him because he had called her a foolish girl
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: anne came back to the royal court and soon king henry fell passionately in love with her
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he wanted her to become his mistress however she categorically refused which made henry's desire for her even greater
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: king henry's marriage to catherine of aragon had produced only one daughter princess mary not thought suitable to rule the country after his death
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: henry needed a son to succeed him and to secure the tudor dynasty but catherine was now too old to have children
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: henry then came to see anne as the answer to the problem of the succession and decided to divorce catherine so that he could marry anne instead and have male heirs
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he said that the marriage was not valid because catherine had been married to his older brother arthur prince of wales before she had married henry
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: arthur had died a few months after the marriage at the age of fifteen and a special dispensation from the pope on the ground the marriage had never been consummated was issued so catherine could marry henry and the alliance between spain and england would be kept
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: king henry now thought that their marriage should not have been allowed in the first place and that they had been punished by not having any sons
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he quoted a verse from the bible that said a man may not marry his brother's wife
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he said he was doing what he thought was right even though he still loved catherine but his conscience would not allow him to continue living in sin with her
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the plans for the divorce caused a lot of gossip at court and abroad and became known as the king's great matter
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a special court was held with wolsey leading it to decide if the divorce should be allowed
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: an official from the pope in rome was brought over and a trial was held
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the official stated that he could not decide what to do
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he wanted the pope to decide instead
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the pope was fearful to offend charles v holy roman emperor nephew of catherine and what would happen if he allowed the divorce
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he did not make a decision
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the meantime anne and king henry were becoming more and more impatient
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: after becoming marquess of pembroke in her own right anne felt secure enough and finally gave in to henry in late 1532 and soon became pregnant
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in order to have a legitimate heir to the throne this meant that anne and henry needed to legalize their union quickly and therefore were secretly married on january 25 1533 even though the divorce had not come through
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: no longer hoping for the pope to grant him a divorce henry's marriage to catherine of aragon was declared illegal in the following may by the newly appointed archbishop of canterbury thomas cranmer former chaplain of the boleyns
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: catherine was sent away from court with the title of dowager princess of wales as if she had never been married to henry
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: now recognized as henry's legal wife anne was formally crowned queen of england on june 1 1533
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: all that was needed now was the birth of a son and her triumph would be complete
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: anne gave birth to a daughter the future elizabeth i of england on september 7 1533
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: king henry was very disappointed after all his troubles the problem of the succession was still not resolved
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: however anne soon became pregnant again but that ended in a miscarriage in the summer of 1534
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: henry started to worry that anne could not give him a healthy male child
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: feeling the king's displeasure anne became more and more insecure and ever more difficult and henry began tiring of her
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the situation only deteriorated when the king began to pay special attention to a lady of the court named jane seymour
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when on january 29 1536 anne gave birth to a stillborn male child henry felt betrayed and completely turned against her accusing her of having bewitched him
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: henry's new secretary thomas cromwell looked for a way to get rid of anne so that henry could marry again
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he found people who said that anne had been the lover of other men while she was married to king henry
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she was put on trial and found guilty of treason adultery and incest although she was probably innocent
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the men who were accused of being her lovers were sir francis weston her musician mark smeaton sir henry norris william brereton and her brother viscount rochford george boleyn
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: all of them were condemned and executed
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: anne was executed on 19 may 1536 in the tower of london london england
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: she was buried in the chapel royal of saint peter ad vincula within the tower of london
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: at the end of the 19th century and the start of the 20th century the city grew quickly

lines.value: some people who study brazilian history says the city was rebuilt

lines.value: in the 20th century many factories were built and more immigrants moved to work there

lines.value: a clot is a semi solid substance that blood forms especially when it is in air
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when a person bleeds the blood turns into a clot at the injury
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a blood clot is also called a thrombus
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the process is called coagulation
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: if a person gets a cut on their body that person may bleed
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: to stop the bleeding the human body does several things
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: first the brain orders the liver to produce chemicals that will help the clot to form
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when the chemicals released by the liver arrive at the injury the coagulation begins
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the mean time the brain also lessens the blood flow near the injury by tightening the veins and arteries in that area so that not as much blood is lost
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there is a limit to how quickly a clot can form
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: if the cut is very deep and the person bleeds too much a clot may not be able to form and a lot of blood may be lost
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: coagulation begins almost instantly after an injury to the blood vessel has damaged the endothelium lining the vessel
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when blood is exposed to proteins such as tissue factor it starts changes to blood platelets and the plasma protein fibrinogen which is a clotting factor
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: platelets immediately form a plug at the site of injury
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: proteins in the blood plasma called coagulation factors or clotting factors respond in a complex cascade to form fibrin strands
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: these strengthen the platelet plug
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: coagulation is highly conserved throughout biology that means its genetics is almost the same in all mammal species
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in all mammals coagulation involves both a cellular platelet and a protein coagulation factor component
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the system in humans has been the most extensively researched and is the best understood
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: fibrin is a white insoluble fibrous protein formed by the action of thrombin on fibrinogen when blood clots
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it forms a network that traps red cells and platelets
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: vitamin k is an essential factor in blood clotting
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: then vitamin k is oxidized
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: another enzyme vitamin k epoxide reductase vkorc reduces vitamin k back to its active form
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this reactivation is important as a target of anticoagulant drug warfarin
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: vitamin k can be found in green vegetables such as spinach lettuce broccoli or cabbage
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the german battleship bismarck was one of the most famous warships of world war ii

lines.value: nearly 3500 seamen lost their lives in the battle which lasted around 8 days

lines.value: the whole ship with all the oil reserves weighed 53165 tonnes
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it was about long and wide
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the ship had eight big guns cannons called the heavy artillery

lines.value: there were 12 smaller cannons and several anti aircraft flak cannons too
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it had very thick armour even for warships today
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the thickest plating was around the heavy artillery where the metal was thick
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: first the bismarck had to reach the open sea
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this because it was a huge battleship few other ships would be able to get close enough to attack without being destroyed so it could control a large area of sea
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the first problem the bismarck had was how to pass the british isles
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it took the way near the fjords of norway
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there it met the other german ship prinz eugen
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: both ships reached the open sea in the denmark straits
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the royal navy's battleships hms hood and hms prince of wales were sent to sink the bismarck
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the hood lost this battle
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the hood was more than a ship for the british military leaders
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it was kind of a myth
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: so the british navy sent a large number of ships to hunt the bismarck
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there were some cruisers many battleships and some aircraft carriers
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there was a very dramatic hunt because the bismarck was damaged but escaped from the nearest british ships
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: finally the bismarck was found by a some aircraft from one of the ships and its rudder and propeller were broken by the torpedoes they carried
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: then the british battleships hms king george v and hms rodney moved down to their shortest range 3km and fired straight into the ships towers one 16 inch shell hit the bridge and killed the captain and the german admiral
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: now the bismarck could not move send radio or fight back due to its fire control taking a direct hit and it was already taking on water due to its duel with hms hood and the abandon ship order had been given so all the of the british ships except two cruisers to pick the german sailors left the bismarck
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: but they had to leave lots behind because a u boat u49 had been sent to find and take the bismarcks log book back to germany
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: with the risk of the bismarck being captured her sailors seriously damaged her and she sank at 10:39

lines.value: vegans avoid food that comes from animals including meat eggs and dairy products like milk cheese and yogurt
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a vegan diet is sometimes called a strict vegetarian diet
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: some vegans also do not eat honey
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: many vegans try not to use any other animal products such as leather wool feathers bone or pearl
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they also try to avoid products that have been tested on animals
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they may believe in animal rights and may campaign for it.vegans eat fruits vegetables beans grains nuts and seeds and things made from them like vegan sweets vegan cheese and vegan cakes
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: donald watson made the word vegan in 1944
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: some people become vegan because they disagree with the treatment of animals in the modern animal farm industry
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: other reasons to become vegan are for health religious reasons to protect the environment or because of world hunger
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: animals eat a lot and take up a lot of resources
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: by not producing meat milk or eggs a lot of food land as of 2006 30% of the earth's land mass is used raising animals for food ) and water can be saved
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: for instance it takes about 16 pounds of grain to make 1 pound of grain fed meat so eating plants directly takes fewer resources
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: some vegans only eat foods that have not been cooked
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: their diet is called raw veganism
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: another more restrictive type of veganism is fruitarianism
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: fruitarians only eat foods that can be harvested without harming or killing a plant
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: vegans must make sure their intake of vitamin b 12 is adequate since it does not occur reliably in plant foods
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: vitamin b 12 deficiency can have serious consequences such as anemia and neurodegenerative disease
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: vegan societies recommend that vegans either eat foods fortified with b 12 or take a b 12 supplement
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: tempeh seaweed spirulina organic produce soil and intestinal bacteria have not been shown to be reliable sources of b 12 for the dietary needs of vegans
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: vitamin d deficiency is possible in the absence of dairy products which are normally fortified with vitamin d
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it can be prevented by supplements and time spent outdoors
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: many people think that it is not healthy to be vegan
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: however a vegan diet can have all of the nutrients needed for health
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is just more difficult to get the nutrients because there are fewer foods to choose from
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: *vegetarianism
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: binoculars are a kind of tool that lets people see far away things more clearly using a technology called optics
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they are made of a pair of matched telescopes that are held in front of the user's eyes
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the two telescopes have lenses that focus light and magnify the image a process called
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this way when someone looks through the binoculars at a far away object it looks much closer
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they have prisms inside which bend the light so to shorten the length of the tubes
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: that is why a binocular is shorter than standard telescopes of similar power
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: binoculars were invented in the 17th century
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they allow a telescope user to use both eyes
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the royal navy used single telescopes but now all ships have heavy binoculars
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: heavy ones can be mounted on swivels to scan the horizon
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: binoculars are also standard issue in all armies
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: night vision binoculars use photocathode electronics to intensify the image
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: binoculars are also used for theatre opera glasses birdwatching and amateur astronomy
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: these features are present in some or all binoculars
